title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.1:ADOLESCENTS LIVING WITH/AT RISK OF HIV

description.narrative: New ElementOutput 2.1: Adolescents living with or at risk of HIV have increased capacity to demand quality prevention, identification, care, and support services., which contributes to Cross-Sectoral - Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 2:By the end of 2023, adolescents (10 to 19 years), particularly the most vulnerable, benefit from gender-responsive quality health, HIV, learning and protection services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: New ElementOutput 2.1: Adolescents living with or at risk of HIV have increased capacity to demand quality prevention,identification, care, and support services.

description.narrative: Through UNICEF support, Lesotho is the first country in the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region to develop sub-national facility-level targets for HIV to improve programme efficiency. UNICEF supported interventions in the HIV sector to ensure continuity of services during COVID-19. As a result, UNICEF reached a total of 12,091 adolescents and young people with information on sexual and reproductive health HIV and COVID-19 through peer-to-peer mentoring, civic participation, and social accountability, which is over 100% achievement of the annual target. 400 young mothers received MHPSS and were referred to healthcare services during the COVID19 pandemic. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:13/12/2021
